bestBHT.bht: The community of goods in the church at Jerusalem did not last long, as only the poor among the saints were the recipients of this contribution. Macedonia and Achaia willingly provided this support, recognizing the indebtedness of the Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. Not all the saints were poor, but Acts and Galatians confirm that many were. Despite the extreme dearth, it is clear that not all the saints were able to provide for their brethren, as some were barely able to subsist themselves.

Henry Alford: This shews the community of goods in the church at Jerusalem not to have lasted long."
The poor among the saints which are at Jerusalem.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For Macedonia and Achaia have thought good to make a certain contribution for the poor of the saints which are at Jerusalem.
They have thought it good and their debtors verily they are.
And well they may, considering what the Gentile believers owe to their Jewish brethren.
Albert Barnes: Paul sought not only to relieve them by this contribution, but also to promote fellow-feeling between them and the Gentile Christians.
Nothing tends so much to wear off prejudice, and to prevent unkind feeling in regard to others, as to set about some purpose 'to do them good,' or to unite 'with' them in doing good.
Marvin Vincent: Poor saints [πτωχους των αγιων] . More literally, and better, the poor of the saints. Rev., among the saints. All the saints were not poor.
Philip Schaff: Thought it good; ‘were well-pleased,’ willingly did this service.
No contribution belongs to Christian charity unless it is willingly bestowed and as a matter of fellowship.
Community of goods evidently did not exist in the church of Jerusalem.
Archibald T. Robertson: For Macedonia and Achaia took pleasure.
Not all there were poor, but Acts 4:32-5; Acts 6:1-6; Acts 11:29; Galatians 2:10 prove that many were.
John Gill: the collection is here called a contribution, or 'communion', as the word signifies; it being one part of the communion of churches and of saints
the persons for whom the collection was made, are 'the poor saints', or 'the poor of the saints'; for not all the saints, but the poor among them, were the objects of this generosity
they considered them as members of the same body, as belonging to the same family, and as standing in the same spiritual relation to God and Christ with themselves
John Wesley: The poor of the saints that are in Jerusalem — It can by no means be inferred from this expression, that the community of goods among the Christians was then ceased.
All that can be gathered from it is, that in this time of extreme dearth, Acts 11:28,29, some of the church in Jerusalem were in want.
The rest being barely able to subsist themselves, but not to supply the necessities of their brethren.

bhtAttempts.bht: The community of goods in the church at Jerusalem did not last long, as only the poor among the saints were the recipients of this contribution. Macedonia and Achaia willingly provided this support for the poor saints in Jerusalem, recognizing the indebtedness of the Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. It is important to note that not all the saints were poor, but Acts and Galatians confirm that many were. The cheerful and voluntary nature of this contribution aimed to promote fellowship and unity between different groups of believers. This collection for the poor saints represented the communion of churches and the sense of belonging to the same spiritual family. Despite the extreme dearth at the time, it is clear that not all the saints were able to provide for their brethren, as some were barely able to subsist themselves.

The community of goods in the church at Jerusalem did not last long, as only the poor among the saints were the recipients of this contribution. Macedonia and Achaia willingly provided this support, recognizing the indebtedness of the Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. Not all the saints were poor, but Acts and Galatians confirm that many were. Despite the extreme dearth, it is clear that not all the saints were able to provide for their brethren, as some were barely able to subsist themselves.

The community of goods in the church at Jerusalem did not last long, as only the poor among the saints were the recipients of this contribution. Macedonia and Achaia willingly provided this support, recognizing the indebtedness of the Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. Not all the saints were poor, but Acts and Galatians confirm that many were. This collection for the poor saints represented the communion of churches and the sense of belonging to the same spiritual family. Despite the extreme dearth at the time, it is clear that not all the saints were able to provide for their brethren.

The contribution made by Macedonia and Achaia for the poor saints in Jerusalem reflects the recognition of the debt owed by Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. This act of support aimed to promote fellowship and unity among different groups of believers. While not all the saints were in poverty, Acts and Galatians attest to the existence of many who were. Despite the existence of a community of goods, the collection of this contribution acknowledges the inability of all the saints to provide for their brethren.

The contribution made by Macedonia and Achaia for the poor saints in Jerusalem evidences the recognition of the debt owed by Gentile believers to their Jewish brethren. This act of support aimed to promote fellowship and unity among different groups of believers. While not all the saints were in poverty, Acts and Galatians confirm that many were. Despite the existence of a community of goods, the collection of this contribution acknowledges the inability of all the saints to provide for their brethren in the midst of extreme dearth.
